response.answer_text: We're telling you that your feelings don't trump our rights. Consider the following. Do black people care that the black power flag offends whites? Do Mexicans care that the Mexican flag offends Americans? Do gay people care that the rainbow flag offends religious conservatives? The answer in all cases is no. The contention of many blacks is that the rebel flag is a racist symbol, therefore it should be banned, or at least considered in poor taste. The problem is that this is a matter of perspective. White Southerners don't even think of blacks when we fly it, so it's not racist in our minds. The counterargument is that the flag was carried by the army of a nation that legalized slavery. The rebel flag, it's claimed, represented legal slavery in the CSA. Slavery, however, was only legal for four years in the CSA. The American flag represented a slaveholding nation for nearly a century. So why aren't blacks more offended by the American flag? The flag of Lee's Army has nothing to do with slavery. It's a symbol of Southern pride, of our ancestors who died fighting yankee aggression. We're still fighting it to this day.

The Confederate flag at the historic house museum here in Alabama where I was curator was associated with the father of the 7 children who grew up in the house - and lived there as adults. The father had been in the Confederate army and was captured at Spotsylvania. The flag was provided by members of his regiment when he died. Next to the Confederate flag is the U.S. Flag similarly sent by the US Navy to be used in the funeral of a son who had been designated a war hero of the Spanish American war and served in the US Congress. There are also relics of another son who graduated from West Point. (The oldest son was a geologist. No military connections that I found). What does the Confederate Flag mean to this family? Well for the seven children who grew to adults and lived here I would guess that story would be different for each of them. To visitors, I think it says from this family (at least for the men) “my country right or wrong”. To say that Confederate soldiers and the Confederate flag would be in a Southern home is treason against the United States only points up how illogical the current phase of historic re-interpretation is: The Confederate flag was (now removed out of fear) behind the nameplate of the Spanish ship that son#2 sunk to block the Spanish fleet and win the Spanish-American War in favor of the United States. Within10 ft from the Confederate flag is the US flag commemorating the heroism of son #2. If the Confederate Flag stands for “Treason” that’s certainly NOT the interpretation of this family whose sons again and again offered their lives for the defense of their Alabama homeland.

To me personally it’s a matter of pride and history. I have a distant relative who was a corporal in the Confederate Army’s Cavalry Division in the south east. So this is one reason it means something to me. The other is the fact that it’s history and heritage to me at least from living in the south. This flag does not and has never been a symbol of slavery as too many people often think. PIease pick up a history book from around or before 1950 or so and follow along. The civil war was fought over taxes. The abolishment of slavery itself didn’t come along until about two years into the war itself in an attempt to reunite the Union and this is why it is often misconstrued that the war over slavery and not taxes.. Not to mention the benefit of having colored regiments bolstering the ranks of the Union forces. The movie Glory gives a good depiction of how the colored regiments, while often in supporting roles rather than frontline battle were still important to the Union forces. So the message for me is that it symbolizes the secession of the states from the Union. There’s so much history here and not enough time. If you wanna know more please feel free to message me. I love history and would love to further this conversation and for anyone who would like to comment, please keep it civil and I will happily entertain further conversation here as well.

Back in the the late 60s, early 70s the Confederate flag was often displayed by teens and twenty somethings as a rebelleous statement. Damn the establishment, damn the war, we will make our own path. It had nothing to do with promoting slavery or disrespecting blacks. It was saying ‘up yours' to the government, deep state, and society.

That we have a symbol representing the pride we have for where we come from. We have our own region of the country that’s ties and bonds are far greater than any other part of the US could ever claim. Regardless of what the motives were at that time, we wanted and fought for independence JUST LIKE THE US DID LESS THAN 90 YEARS PREVIOUSLY! There’s a tremendous amount of pride in the states that banded together to fight for one another and that won’t change. That’s what I’m telling you when I fly the battle flag.
